question: How to route high-speed breakout signals in dense BGA regions?
options: A
All signals can be fanned out through the top layer to simplify routing complexity
B
Staggered traces and blind/buried via technology are used to prioritize fanning out to the inner layer to maintain signal integrity
C
High-speed signals can be fanned out alternately through multiple wiring layers to reduce cross-coupling
D
Use long wire connections near the BGA to reduce the use of wiring layers
E
None of the above options are correct

question: How to prevent stub structures from affecting high-speed signal quality?
options: A
Back drilling technology is used to remove the via stub structure to avoid unnecessary T branches
B
Solve the problems caused by the stub structure by adding multiple layers of shielding and external filters
C
Filter capacitors are installed next to all high-speed signals to eliminate reflections in the signal
D
Arrange the signal in a serpentine structure to increase the reflection path and avoid affecting the quality
E
None of the above options are correct
